title: Olympics - Bobsleigh - We tied? Chaos after Canada-Germany dead-heat
text: 19 PM / Updated 15 minutes ago Bobsleigh: We tied? Chaos after Canada-Germany dead-heat James Pearson 3 Min Read PYEONGCHANG,   It was one of the closest sliding races in Olympic history, but when Canada’s Justin Kripps and Alexander Kopacz rocketed over the finish line in the two-man bobsleigh final on Monday, they knew they had secured gold. Trouble was, Germany’s Francesco Friedrich and Thorsten Margis had also won the race. Kripps had put together three good runs, consistently placing first or second, and he needed to pull out another one to secure his first Olympic gold medal. Friedrich set the fastest time but Kripps, in the final run of the competition, exactly matched his mark of three minutes 16.86 seconds. “It took me a couple of minutes. We were in the changing room and I asked Thorsten and I said I‘m not sure I understood what just happened, did we tie?,” Canadian brakeman Kopacz said. Knowing that it had been a tie - the first in the two-man bobsleigh event since Nagano in 1998 - an overjoyed Friedrich and Margis had rushed over to Kripps and Kopacz to celebrate as they finished their final run. “At first I thought we had won outright but then these guys jumped over and were super excited and I thought ‘Wow these guys are really happy for us!',” said Kripps, who thought the Germans had been ecstatic about winning silver. Bobsleigh - Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympics - Men's 2-man Finals - Olympic Sliding Centre - Pyeongchang, South Korea - February 19, 2018 - Gold medalists Francesco Friedrich and Thorsten Margis of Germany celebrate with gold medalists Alexander Kopacz and Justin Kripps of Canada during the victory ceremony. REUTERS/Edgar Su “Thorsten was giving me a hug and he said it was like three hundredths, two hundredths... and then a tie.” “It’s crazy,” Kripps said. Bobsleigh - Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympics - Men's 2-man Finals - Olympic Sliding Centre - Pyeongchang, South Korea - February 19, 2018 - Francesco Friedrich and Thorsten Margis of Germany react. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann Amid the ensuing chaos, it had taken Kripps a while to find his brakeman to tell him. “It was a sea of emotions, a sea of team mates and tears from my parents,” Kopacz said. “Lots of yelling and then we were hustled over to the changing room and I realised we tied.” It wasn’t until Friedrich and Margis explained that the gap had been closing by three hundredths of a second, then two hundredths, then one hundredths, that the Canadian pair knew what was going on. “They got it when we told them the full time,” said Friedrich who also came joint-first in the four-man bob at last year’s world championships. “They got it that we had a tie.” Kripps learnt how to pilot his sled from Canadian Olympian Pierre Lueders - the same athlete who was involved in a dead heat for first place with Italy in Nagano. “It was really fun to tie with these guys,” Kripps said. “Two more guys who are as happy as you are.” Reporting by James Pearson, editing by Ed Osmond
